Award.AwardTitle: Rapid chemical imaging with sum-frequency generation microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Eric Potma of the University of California, Irvine, is developing a fast laser-scanning nonlinear optical (NLO) microscope platform that includes a new chemically selective imaging modality: sum-frequency generation (SFG). This advance offers researchers active in the fields of biology and materials research a new form of chemical imaging contrast, which was previously not available at practical acquisition speeds and resolution. The addition of the SFG modality onto the optical microscope relies on new achromatic optical components, which are especially designed and developed in this project, and which may find important new applications in other forms of infrared imaging and microscopy. Further broader impacts of this work include the use of the SFG imaging platform as a training tool in a biophysics graduate course and the development of community-oriented, interactive walking tours through local wildlands that illuminate biophysical effects in nature.

This project integrates the unique imaging capabilities of SFG into a laser-scanning optical microscope. SFG makes it possible to visualize a special class of materials, namely those that exhibit non-centrosymmetry on a molecular level. Because SFG is also sensitive to molecular vibrations, the resulting images can differentiate non-centrosymmetric materials based on their chemical bond vibrations. As an imaging modality, this contrast mechanism enables researchers to perform detailed studies on a myriad of materials, including biological fibers and chiral microcrystals, at image acquisition speeds that have hitherto remained out of reach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of chemical imaging with optical microscopy is to produce images with contrast based the chemical composition of the sample. Fluorescence microscopy, by far the most popular optical imaging technique for imaging of biological sample, achieves this by tagging the molecules of interest with fluorescent labels. Yet, label-free methods are often preferred, as fluorescent labels can compromise the specimen and product artificial contrast. Label-free imaging with chemical contrast can be challenging, as not all molecular targets respond to optical illumination in a unique and detectable manner. The most general approach to label-free chemical imaging is to use the vibrational motions of chemical groups, which have distinct vibrational spectroscopic signatures. These are the signatures that are probed in the two conventional vibrational microscopy techniques: Raman microscopy and infrared (IR) absorption microspectroscopy. These techniques make use of the two fundamental forms of the vibrational response of molecules when illuminated with optical radiation, namely the Raman-activity and the IR-activity of molecular vibrational modes.

 

Raman and IR-absorption microscopy techniques are good solutions to many imaging problems. However, if both speed and high-resolution are required, these traditional forms of vibrational microscopy can no longer be used. In this area, high-speed and high-resolution vibrational imaging, new developments are needed. In this regard, coherent Raman scattering (CRS) techniques have made a significant impact, as they fulfill both of these needs. CRS can be considered a nonlinear optical analogues of Raman microscopy, offering similar imaging contrast based on Raman-active molecular vibrations but at much higher imaging acquisition speeds. CRS microscopy techniques have been used for a variety of imaging applications, most notably in cell biology, but also in material sciences. 

 

Whereas the breakthroughs in CRS have enabled new chemical imaging applications based on the Raman-activity of molecular vibrations, there has not been an equivalent development of techniques that improve the imaging capabilities based on the IR-activity of molecules. In this project, nonlinear vibrational imaging techniques were developed that significantly improved the imaging capabilities of conventional IR absorption microscopy techniques. 

 

The first technique that was developed in this project is sum-frequency generation (SFG) microscopy. In this approach, a molecular vibration is driven with mid-IR light, but it is probed with a second laser beam of a different color. This probing beam is `up-converting’ the IR-transition in the molecule into an optical signal in the visible range of the spectrum. This has two important advantages: 1) the signal can be detected with affordable and efficient detectors in the visible range of the spectrum, and 2) the probing spot is much smaller than in regular IR-microscopy because the probing wavelength is much shorter. A new, laser-scanning SFG microscope was built as part of this project, enabling the acquisition of vibrationally sensitive SFG images at 1 frame/second. This novel system delivered so-called hyper-spectral images, where each pixel contains an SFG spectrum, with a spatial resolution of 0.6 micrometer. The SFG contrast enables the selective visualization of structures that are non-centrosymmetric. The system was used to image and characterize molecular specific structure and orientation in collagen fibers, cellulose fibers and cholesterol crystals. 

 

The second technique that was developed in this project is third-order sum-frequency generation (TSFG) microscopy. Like SFG microscopy, it probes IR-transitions of molecules, which makes it sensitive to vibrational motions of chemical groups. In addition, TSFG is also fully integrated into a laser-scanning microscope, enabling rapid imaging and detection with visible light detectors. However, the imaging properties of TSFG are rather different from SFG. Whereas SFG visualizes structures that display non-centrosymmetry, TSFG does not have the same symmetry-restriction that SFG has, as it is sensitive to any structural arrangement in the sample. Consequently, TSFG is a very general IR-sensitive imaging technique, capable of producing images with the same contrast as seen in existing IR-microspectroscopy methods. The significant advance is that TSFG can produce those images at a resolution that is one order of magnitude higher than what is common in conventional IR-based microscopy. Hence, structures that are otherwise overlooked with conventional microscopy can now be resolved with TSFG microscopy. The TSFG technique is entirely novel, and it can be expected that its unique imaging properties will open up new chemical imaging applications in biology and material science.

 

As part of these developments, new lenses were designed and fabricated. These lenses are so-called super-achromats, which make it possible to focus light on the mid-IR and in the visible range to a common focal spot without aberrations. Such lenses were not commercially available and were especially designed for this project. The super-achromats have proven very powerful and have increased the SFG/TSFG image quality and throughput considerably. These lenses have now been fully prototyped, tested and batch produced, for the purpose of serving other optical engineers in the field.
